data.title: Crash in SharpDX when rendering line strip
data.body:
We're getting:

```
SharpDXException was unhandled

HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [Unknown], ApiCode: [Unknown/Unknown], Message: The parameter is incorrect.
```

on line 2094 of GraphicsDevice.cs when trying to render a dynamic line strip with the following code:

``` csharp
var vertexes = new[]
{
    new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(40, 20, 0), Color.White),
    new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(80, 50, 0), Color.White),
    new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(120, 60, 0), Color.White),
    new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(160, 100, 0), Color.White),
};
var indicies = new short[] { 0, 1, 2, 3 };

gameContext.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawUserIndexedPrimitives<VertexPositionColor>(
    PrimitiveType.LineStrip,
    vertexes,
    0,
    vertexes.Length,
    indicies,
    0,
    vertexes.Length - 1);
```

This should work fine according to Microsoft's examples on LineStrip, but it doesn't.  Other types of primitives seem to render fine.

What we're actually trying to do is render a graph, with the vertexes generated every frame.  The code above is substituted for the block at https://github.com/hach-que/Tychaia/blob/master/Tychaia/Profiling/TychaiaProfilerEntity.cs#L111, which is being rendered from https://github.com/hach-que/Tychaia/blob/master/Tychaia/TychaiaWorldManager.cs#L73.  Again, according to Microsoft's examples, this should work.

We did at one point manage to get it to run for a few frames, but then it would still crash almost immediately after startup.

data.title: Significantly improve OpenAL performance/memory usage
data.body:
Take two of https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1841

Original Pull Request write-up below.

This pull request addresses two primary flaws in the current OpenAL audio backend for MonoGame:

**_1. Audio data is needlessly held on to after it has been given to OpenAL.**_

You will notice that we remove byte[] arrays in OALSoundBuffer and SoundEffectInstance in this patch. The code in those files implies that we need the data for purposes other than loading directly into OpenAL, but no code in MonoGame currently uses this. So, we essentially keep a duplicate copy of_ every single OpenAL buffer_ for the duration of the program's runtime unless we explicitly destroy the data ourselves.

By simply removing these from the files, we improve memory use drastically, and for XACT, we improve it _by at least 50%_.

**_2. Redundant decoding/rewriting of wavedata is performed presumably to reuse the public API.**_

While it makes sense on paper, the fact is we're decoding header data only to reencode it when we're "done" in a single method multiple times for every single audio file that gets loaded into MonoGame. This can possibly introduce memory problems like those found in bullet one, and it's also a pretty goofy waste of resources when we can just send the data to internal methods that will eventually give it to OpenAL.

By fixing these two issues, performance for XACT/SoundEffects on OpenAL has improved immensely (mostly in regard to memory use, CPU use certainly improves but is not noticeable on high-end machines).
